name: Greek Arts and Literature Quiz / Test | Humanities | 10 Questions

questions.text: The opening line of a play by which playwright reads: 'Ismene, dear sister, You would think that we had already suffered enough...'?
questions.explanation:
Sophocles.

	This is the opening line of 'Antigone'. Greek drama developed from celebrations honoring Dionysus...(it says 'interesting info'...this isn't interesting is it?)

questions.text: Which poet wrote: 'Water is best, and gold, like a blazing fire in the night, stands out supreme of all lordly wealth.'?
In which of his plays did Aristophanes write: 'Well. I'm afraid you've come a fool's errand. Your wives have gone.'?
questions.explanation:
Lysistrata.

	This is probably the source of the phrase 'fool's errand'.

questions.text: Who wrote that a life of reason was: 'a life in the possession of intelligence, thought, knowledge, and a complete memory of everything, but without an atom of pleasure, or indeed pain, in a condition of utter insensibility to such things.'?
questions.explanation:
Plato.

	This is from 'Dialogues with Philebus'.  The quote is from Socrates in the dialogue.

questions.text: Which of the following is not credited with being an architect of the Parthenon?
questions.explanation:
Gorgias.

	Phidias handled most of the sculptural work, while the other two focused on the actually planning of the building.

questions.text: To what age was Ovid referring when he wrote: 'Truth, modesty, and shame, the world forsook: Fraud, avarice, and force, their places took.'?
questions.explanation:
The Iron Age & Iron Age.

	This is from Ovid's 'Metamorphosis' (Book the First).

questions.text: Which poet wrote: 'Tonight I've watched -- the moon and then -- the Pleiades -- go down -- The night is now -- half-gone; youth -- goes; I am --in bed alone.'?
questions.explanation:
Sappho.

	One of my favorite poems of this famous ancient poet from the island of Lesbos (as many of my friends are aware since I force it on them often).

Diogenes.

	I know...everyone has said this...but ostensibly this famous cynic who lived in a tub said it first.

questions.text: Who said: 'We can only explain you, young man, by assuming that your father was drunk the night he begot you.'?
questions.explanation:
Diogenes.

	I know...I know...two Diogenes questions in a row...but I couldn't resist.  Who could resist a man who had the temerity to ask Alexander the Great to step out of his light?

questions.text: It was said of which Greek artist that his grapes were so lifelike birds tried to peck at them?
questions.explanation:
Zeuxis.

	Zeuxis and Parrhasios were rather intense rivals. Parrhasios invited Zeuxis in to view a painting which he had covered by a curtain. When Zeuxis went to lift the curtain, he discovered it was nothing but paint.
